reviewText:
So this what it feels like ? So this is what the wait for Half Life 3 feels like.

Half Life 2 Episode Two is the sequel to Episode One and begins straight away. We find ourselves in the outskirts of City 17 as the Citadel has now opened a portal to the Combines home world and it's now up to us to find a way to the rebel base and shut down the portal once and for all.

The gameplay is identical to previous titles in the Half Life 2 games.  Overall there's not much to say here as it's basically DLC to Half Life 2.

Graphics wise this game looks a tad bit better than Half Life 2 due to the range rendering, which I thought was under used in Half Life 2 Episode One. The portal coming from the citadel can be seen throughout the entire game which looks outstanding.

There is a reason this is my favorite Half Life title and that's the action sequences. This game is like a great action movie. Action scenes after action scenes after action scenes and it all ends up to one of the biggest cliffhanger endings in history of gaming. I'm not joking it actually pains me not knowing what happens next.

I also love the incredible soundtrack. It's beyond kick ♥♥♥ and is one of my favorite game soundtracks of all time.

In the end Half Life 2 Episode Two is a thrilling ride and it should be played by everyone. I'm glad I finally joined the bandwagon. Now I can join the Half Life 3 waiting community.

Final Rating:
10/10 - A must own and a must play

reviewText:
Nice told with Alyx

HALF-LIFE 2 EPISODE 2 starts immediately where Half-Life 2 Episode 1 ended. Gordon Freeman and Alyx Vance must continue their fight, alongside the resistance, against the evil Combine. After the ever so slightly below par Episode 1, Episode 2 is a real return to form. Everything that was so good about HL2 is developed here and made even better. The narrative arc is strong, the dialogue well-written and witty, the voice acting accomplished and convincing, the environments spectacular and varied, and the mix between puzzle solving and combat just right. We meet several new enemies and some of the combat is pretty challenging, especially the final battle which is big on scale and mayhem and requires real strategy to complete. It’s a tough finale but well worth the effort. There’s so much to enjoy in the whole Half-Life series I can’t recommend these games enough.

5/5

Half Life 2 is a first person shooter game released in 2004. It was awarded as the Game of the Decade in the VGA Awards. The award was received by Gabe Newell, Valve founder.

The game takes place 20 years after the Black Mesa incident of Half Life ( The game that chaged it all ) . Gordon Freeman awakes from hibernation in City 17 and become part of the resistance to face the Combine Empire and attempt to defeat it. In the game Gordon meets Alyx Vance,  who is part of the resistance. The game is one of the pioneers in introducing a playmate .

Half Life 2 presents different enemies . The Headcrabs still produce that feeling of rejection when they attack. The action is breathtaking but it breaks , not like Call of Duty games where you shoot without breathing.

The narrative is implemented throughout the game, not with recording or notes , it is not necessary. The experience is brilliant. The Source engine allows good management of physics and the introduction of a new weapon. The gravity gun . The technology also allows open spaces in addition to traditional outdoor passageways and internal spaces .

The handling of the narrative and physics puzzles changed the way the FPS games developed from there into the future . It was a turning point in games history the same way it was the first Half Life .

The game was released for PC under Windows , required a 2 Ghz processor . 512 MB ​​of RAM , and a graphics card compatible with Direct X 8.1 . For the few resources sought at that time the graphical quality of the game was very good and ran very smoothly .

This is one of the must play" games if one is serious about being a Gamer

reviewText:
Half-Life 2: Episode Two continues the human resistances fight against the Combine, with you once again playing the role of Gordon Freeman. It takes place immediately following the occurrences of Episode One, and contains somewhere between 4-5 hours of quality content depending on how you play it.

Episode Two does a great job progressing the title through every aspect when compared to Episode One, just like Episode One did in comparison to the base game. With Episode Two you will find slightly updated visuals by the way of textures and lighting, various new mechanics, and a couple of new enemies and weapon types. However, the narrative is easily what develops the most, which is at the same time the most frustrating part of this installment. Great strides were made into understanding the plot, you become more invested than ever, and then BOOM! Everything is stopped in its tracks, a huge cliff hanger occurs, and nearly a decade later there is no extension to the series. I took all the self-control I had to get this far still writing a genuinely informative review, so I'm just going to let it all out now.

Personal Rating: ♥♥♥♥ YOU VALVE (10)/10

I shall live and die with the vortigaunts. I am the crowbar in the darkness. I am the researcher in the labs. I am the missile that burns against the Combine, the light that brings the end of their days, the siren that wakes the sleepers, the shield that guards the realms of men. reviewText:
Because the soundtrack is the best of the Half-Life universe and because you want to see the gnome in the rocket. Alyx's ♥♥♥ is also counting if you're a certain friend of mine.

The game is starting after the crash of your train and the destruction of City 17. You're alone with Alyx in a forest and after finding an abandoned outpost, you're attacked by an enemy you've never seen before. Alyx is badly wounded and her life is at stake, only Vortigaunts can save her. And from there, you're going to a journey in a mine. And reaching the White Forest base will take time too.

This episode was released in the Orange Box, that is including Half-Life 2, Episode 1, Portal and Team Fortress 2. It was the first Half-Life on PC to have achievements, because of the release on X-box.

While the game is short, the episode is still intense as you're meeting more Antlions (and new types too), you have to defend the outpost from them in an intense battle, a new car makes its appearance, a new combine type is also making its debut, spicing up the game but also, you're finally face to face to a real Combine. And that's scary because you can't do anything about it.

The White Forest ambush is also a good moment but the most difficult passage is White Forest defense against Striders. If they reach the base, it's game over. But with the Magnusson devices, you can quickly kill them. If you manage to make them stick, that's it.

However, while this passage is really hard for the achievement with no building destroyed, the most annoying quest (for achievement, you're not forced to do it) is to bring the gnome to the rocket. And the gnome in your car?  Well, it's falling off every 5 seconds. So, in other words, you're going forward, stop the car, get the gnome back, restart the engine, advance, stop the car, etc... And another one that can rival that is to kill every Antlion larva in the mine (333 to crush) and some of them are well hidden.

With the cliffhanger, you'll understand why it's since 8 years that we're waiting for the Episode 3. Or Half-Life 3.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Half-Life 2: Episode Two was the last of the weird counting method Valve used to make sure they didn't need to count to three. Half-Life 2: Episode Two was developed by Valve Corporation and released late 2007.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: The story picks up, right where Half-Life 2: Episode One left off; Alyx Vance and Gordon Freeman are going to be reunited with Eli Vance and Dr. Kleiner to plan the next step in their battle against the Combine forces.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=520577049

Gameplay: This game returns to the more familiar setting of Half-Life 2, you aren't forced to rely solely on the Gravity gun like in most of Half-Life 2: Episode One. There is a new NPC that you encounter called “Hunters”, these are savage killing machines that are very imposing and at times down right freighting when encountered.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=520577103

Achievements: There are 22 achievements on Half-Life 2: Episode Two. One third of the achievements are unlocked just by playing through the story. The rest are pretty tough and require careful planning, or a very long time running around.
The most noteworthy achievements in this game are: Get Some Grub (“Squish every antlion grub in Episode Two” – That took forever.), and Little Rocket Man (requiring you to Carry a Garden Gnome from the beginning of the game to nearly the end) – I have an obsession with garden gnomes because of this achievement, stay away from the precious!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=520577080

Price: Half-Life 2: Episode Two is priced at $7.99, you're better off purchasing The Orange Box for $19.99, where you will gain all the Half-Life 2 games + Portal 1.

Conclusion: I think Half-Life 2: Episode One, and Half-Life 2: Episode Two, really should have been one amazing game. Separate they're short but sweet. To quickly recap, Story: Excellent. Gameplay: nearly identical to the previous games. Achievements: Getting 100% completed will take longer then Half-Life 2, or Episode One. Price: a bit high, but the orange box is an excellent deal for the whole series.
I recommend this game to anyone who's played Half-Life 2 and Half-Life 2: Episode One. You don't want to jump into this game, you will want to play the previous games first.

Continuing the plot of Half-Life 2 and Episode One, Episode Two consists of seven chapters telling the story of Gordon Freeman and Alyx Vance's journey to a large Lambda Resistance base called White Forest. The Combine's Earth occupation forces have used the destruction of the Citadel to begin opening a massive super portal which, if allowed to reach critical size, would allow the Combine to call in reinforcements from their homeworld and destroy the Resistance. However, as explained by Dr. Kleiner's broadcast in Episode One, it has also caused a communications blackout, leaving the Combine isolated and disorganized in the meantime. In addition, Combine Advisors, some of them still unhatched from their pods, are scattered about the region after evacuating the Citadel. A crucial part of the plot is the Combine's message home, which was copied by Alyx and Gordon before making their escape, that the Combine sacrificed the Citadel to send. It contains data on the Combine portal code, which the Resistance can use to collapse the portal before it forms completely.

After Gordon and Alyx climb out of the wreckage of the train they used to escape City 17, they proceed away from the former city on foot. At an old transmission station, the duo temporarily establish communication with Dr. Kleiner and Eli Vance, who are currently at White Forest. After an update of events at the now-destroyed Citadel, as well discovering the importance of the transmission packet copy that Alyx had made, they are cut off as Combine sweep the area, forcing them to move. At an abandoned mine, Alyx is critically wounded by a Hunter. A vortigaunt discovers them, and leads them to an underground Resistance shelter. The vortigaunts there have the power to heal Alyx; however, Gordon must first venture into the nearby antlion colony to recover the larval extract necessary for the healing procedure.

Gordon retrieves the extract and the vortigaunts begin to heal Alyx. While they are distracted, the G-Man is able to contact Gordon for the first time since the start of Episode One. He hints at Alyx's importance to his own long-term plans, revealing that he saved Alyx's life at Black Mesa despite objections from an unspecified third party. reviewText:
Half-Life 2: Episode Two is the second story expansion to the original Half-Life 2 by Valve. After escaping from City 17 and the massive explosion that consumed it, Gordon Freeman and Alyx decide to reach the other rebel forces in their secret base in the White Forest area.
As far as gameplay and main structure goes, Episode Two is very similar to the first one: you will basically play a story-driven DLC for four hours or so and be challenged by several gameplay changes and enemies you'll have to overcome in order to advance. If anything, Episode Two is much more action-driven than Episode One: on top of having nearly all your weaponry from the original Half-Life 2, the DLC introduced the toughest enemies in the series yet. It's also worth mentioning that the second episode spots two incredibly nasty achievements, which are a chore to unlock in themselves. As far as story and environments go, Episode Two takes place in entirely new areas from the main game and a more emotional, increasingly intensive plot.
Half-Life 2: Episode Two, much like its predecessor, is a great addition to the original Half-Life 2 and filled with very high quality content

In my opinion HL2E2 is the crowning achievement of everything Valve has released. I have not played with the new graphical mod but even without it this game has some of the most amazing looking graphics I have seen in a video game. reviewText:
Half-Life 2: Episode Two is the second story expansion to the original Half-Life 2 by Valve. After escaping from City 17 and the massive explosion that consumed it, Gordon Freeman and Alyx decide to reach the other rebel forces in their secret base in the White Forest area.
As far as gameplay and main structure goes, Episode Two is very similar to the first one: you will basically play a story-driven DLC for four hours or so and be challenged by several gameplay changes and enemies you'll have to overcome in order to advance. If anything, Episode Two is much more action-driven than Episode One: on top of having nearly all your weaponry from the original Half-Life 2, the DLC introduced the toughest enemies in the series yet. It's also worth mentioning that the second episode spots two incredibly nasty achievements, which are a chore to unlock in themselves. As far as story and environments go, Episode Two takes place in entirely new areas from the main game and a more emotional, increasingly intensive plot.
Half-Life 2: Episode Two, much like its predecessor, is a great addition to the original Half-Life 2 and filled with very high quality content

Half-Life 2: Episode 2 is the direct sequel to Half-Life 2: Episode 1 and is the last Half Life game released. So I was expecting something at least semi-interesting since people have been begging for its sequel for almost 10 years now. And while I didn't come away from the ending with my jaw on the floor, agonizing over when I would be able to play its sequel, I did find it to be an enjoyable experience.

That's not to say it advances the gameplay of the Half Life series in any revolutionary way. But it does take the series' established characters and gameplay into new and interesting territory. You'll still be using the same weapons, fighting most of the same enemies, and moving around in a familiar manner, but there are some interesting new settings to advance through and some slight twists to gameplay which distinguish it enough from the rest of the games in the series, thus offering more of the satisfying gameplay the Half-Life games have been known for.

The story itself is a bit more emotionally tinged this time around. Throughout the journey you'll be to more exposed to the personal thoughts and feelings of the characters than in previous titles. And rest assured the terrffic voice work from past games is still around, and in full form, making these moments worthy of empathy, and instrumental in bringing more life to characters.

Graphically there isn't much to write home about as this is a nine year old game, and it is beginning to show its age. But the Half-Life series' famous art design continues to intruige the eyes and mind so unless you're generaly abhorred by older graphics, they shouldn't dampen your enjoyment of the game. All in all, Episode 2 successfully continues to carry the torch of its predecessors and takes the Half-Life series into some interesting, albeit minimal, fresh terrain.

reviewText:
Where HL2's third day was slow and boring, and Episode One was claustrophobic and close-quarters, Episode Two provides a new experience for the series.

The environments are open and beautiful, and the new vehicle, an old 1970 Dodge Charger, along with the new vehicle physics system makes this vehicle leagues abouve the buggy from HL2.

Victory Mine, the Radio Station, the White Forest Inn, and of course White Forest Missile Base all provide new environments that give different and new experiences to the series.

Arne Magnusson, Uriah, Eli, Kleiner, the Vortiguants, and of course the dynamic duo of Sheckley & Griggs each provide engaging dialogue with everyone, even though Gordon as usual speaks not a word.

The ending however, leaves a feel-bad hole, even now almost six years after first playing it. The fact that we don't have HL3 or Episode Three to see the conclusion makes the ending of the game almost surreal, as we have an incomplete story.

One last thing, that damn gnome, Rufus, is just plain evil. If you're going for 'Little Rocket Man', be prepared to use your quicksave key frequently.

Must avoid mentioning episode 3 here...

Half life 2 was always a great game. This game puts more emphasis on difficult battles in the first half, and vehicle exploration in the second half. The most memorable part has to be the finale, though I wont spoil anything.
This game also continues Episode One's feature of teaming up with Alyx throughout most of the game, who makes a great companion and is a proficient fighter.
Except this, the game is exactly like the previous two games. If you liked those games, this is more than a must-buy. If you didn't, buy it anyway. It is a great game from beginning to end (even if the plot leaves on an unresolved cliffhanger)

Overall, a brilliant game for both half life fans and the first person shooter community. Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
It took me a while to get around to reviewing this one as my aging laptop overheated about halfway through my last attempt to play it, so I had to wait until I had a more powerful one. Not docking points there - towards the end of its life that laptop even had trouble running the base HL2, which initially ran with no problems.

Episode Two is an overall stronger entry into the series than Episode One was, mostly because it had more moments actually worth remembering. All I remember about Episode One is it introduced the Zombines and the climax was a fight with a Strider in a warehouse. However, it's still a weaker product than the core game which I already thought was highly overrated.

Playing this game gave me time to analyze further what made me like HL1 so much and what made HL2 and its children fail to meet that standard. I believe there are two things HL1 did incredibly well that its sequal didn't: variety and ramping of challenge.

Half-Life's suite of challenges were extremely varied, from alien wildlife to zombies to intelligent aliens to marines to black ops ninjas to giant monsters and so forth. HL2 has Gas Mask SWAT Teams From Space, Antlions, Zombies, and Alien Vehicles. And really only that last category is even remotely interesting to fight. Not to mention the constant array of environmental obstacles Half-Life threw at you. By comparison HL2 mostly offers locked doors and the occasional pool of radioactive goo. It's easy to remember the bit with the rail cart, the bit with the tentacle monster in the silo, the bit underwater, the bit in the desert, the bit along the cliff, and so forth in HL1 than it is to remember anything in HL2 besides the ending, Ravenholm, and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ vehicle sections.

But the focus is Episode Two, not an overall look on why HL2 doesn't work as well. Speaking of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ vehicle sections, they're back! And yes they still handle like ♥♥♥. As in a particularly energetic and unfriendly donkey ridden backwards while drunk. Fortunately they only take up about a quarter of the game, leaving another quarter for antlions, one for zombies, and one for War of the Worlds tripods.

Yes while Episode Two does better about being memorable than Episode One, it manages this by throwing all its weight into a handful of things. Which I can respect if done right. One of the biggest failings of sandbox games is their utter failure to focus on anything besides obsessive-compulsive garbage collecting. But that's neiher here nor there. I'm not surprised Valve went on to make Left 4 Dead after this, because they clearly think that zombie killing is the most fun thing ever since any time they turn up (which as mentiond earlier is about a quarter of the game), there are dozens upon dozens of them and the game suddenly feels like Doom in terms of just wading into bodies with the trigger held down.

Going back a moment to HL1's variety and ramping of threat, one of my bigger issues with Episode Two is the ending. Sure it's big and climactic as one might expect, but the issue is that it fails on both counts of HL1's advantages. The climactic challenge is Striders, because of course it is. They were the best part of HL2, they turned up again for the climax of Episode One, and now in Episode Two you blow up about a dozen of them in a single fight.

Now, the reason this is a failure in my eyes is that the overuse of Striders as final bosses cheapens both their intimidation factor and the series ability to present a challenge. If they simply made Striders become periodic minibosses on par with the alien helicopter things it might work, as Striders become part of the greater world and a representation of our own increasing threat level. But by overusing them but still reserving them as final bosses, everyone loses. The Striders stop being intimidating because we know we can beat them, and they stop being credible as final bosses, because now we've killed 20 of the damn things and all of their wow-factor is gone, like if the final boss to a Halo game was just a dozen Hunters in a row (the fact that Halo games have never had a good boss fight is not relevant to the metaphor).

To bring this ramble to resembling a conclusion, Episode Two is not strictly speaking a bad game. Everything it does it does competently. However, I can't recommend it because it simply offers nothing to the conversation except for a cliffhanger leading into a sequel whose nonexistence has turned into an industry punchline. It shows up, it fills the space, it introduces exactly one new enemy type to wave off allegations of being blatant filler content. If you're a Half-Life fan my opinion doesn't matter because you've already bought and played it. If you aren't, skip it and find a game with more to say.

reviewText: I loved the original Half-Life, had to wait 10 years to play all of Half-Life 2, and was sorely disappointed. As a note, I played the entirety of Half-Life 2 through from the beggining and am reviewing the entirety of the series here, not just Episode 2.\n\nRight out of the gate, you're on guard duty. I hate escort missions. You spend the whole game with Alyx Vance three feet behind you, causing me to wish I could shoot her, and whenever you try, you end up with much the same results as Resident Evil 4. Mainly my annoyance with Alyx came whenever I tried to move a bunch of barrels and crates to create make-shift barriers. She just gets in the way and constanltly knocks the object you're holding out of your hands. At least in Resident Evil 4 you could tell Ashley Graham to get out of your face and go hide in a steel trunk. Next, I don't understand first-person shooters that end in a final challenge which involves DRIVING (I.E. Halo & Halo 3). Finally, if you actually manage to make it past the last driving segment, you're treated to an even more poorly written end-game scenario than Blue-Shift, made even worse by the fact that it doesn't look like we'll ever get Half-Life 3, or even Episode 3. At least we have Black Mesa now.

reviewText:
For those looking for a quick review, I'll sum this game up for you by a metaphor:
This game was made from distilled children's tears, and its cover is bound in living human skin. Each copy of this game, is powered by the screaming soul of a forsaken child - or rather a forsaken gamer.

This game, and its predecessor Episode 1, is unique, in that it's not about the actual content inside the game, but the world surrounding it.
Here's some perspective for you:
Half-Life was released in 1998,
Half-Life 2 was released 6 years later (in 2004),
It took six years because Valve was still a small company back then, and when it was released, it revolutionized graphics.
So far so good.

Two years later Valve promised us a trilogy - Half-Life 2: Episode One, Two and Three.
Half-Life 2: Episode One, was released 2006, and Episode Two was released in 2007, Episode Three was released in 2008.

...except no, it wasn't.
It is now 2014, 6 years after the release of Episode Two, and still no sign of Episode Three. Valve tells us that they have largely abandoned single-player games for multi-player games.
Valve has not only forsaken their loyal gamers, but they have also exploited the attention that comes from their faithful waiting, using it to power their unholy platform Steam. They actually built a huge machine out of the torment of their faithful. This is why Steam is the number one gaming platform: Because it it lubricated with human tears, from people suckered in by Episode One and Episode Two.

Readers paying attention will notice that six years passed between Half-Life and Half-Life 2. The promised that Valve sold the episodic content with, was that these episodes were going to be released *more frequently* than the bigger games. That's why we bought the games in the first place: Because we expected Valve to keep their word, and not screw us without shame.

At this point gamers are even beginning to ask themselves: Where is Half-Life 3? You set us up for the cliffhanger many years back, where another six hour war" was impending in the story

reviewText:
Despite slightly prettier visuals, a handful of additions and some mild tweaks, the middle chapter in the now discontinued Half-Life 2: Aftermath trilogy does not do much to improve the original game's already lackluster formula. Worse, it is content with rehashing most of it.

PROS:
+ Finally a separate energy bar for the flashlight!
+ An entire chapter and a half without Alyx!
+ Finally some new environments!
+ Prettier visuals
+ New enemies

CONS:
- Where is Barney?
- The Antlion Worker
- The insufferable Dr. Magnusson
- Contrived melodramatic ending
- The nerve-wracking final battle...
- Lack of notable gameplay innovations
- Alyx Vance's inexplicable importance to the story
- No proper conclusion in the absence of Episode 3
- No new weapon, aside from the frustrating Magnusson Device
- What was the point of dividing Half-Life 2: Aftermath into three games again?
- The G-Man and by extent Valve's continuing unwillingness to address any loose ends
